Titanium will be slightly heavier, but far more durable. I bought a second hand titanium frame, must be 15-20 years old (heavily upgraded now mind) and it is indestructible. The main reason that titanium bikes are slightly more expensive is because the tools used to make them get worn down so quickly due to how hard the material is. If you crash on titanium, you might end up with a dent in a tube or something slightly bent...crash on carbon and impact force can easily totally destroy a bike beyond repair. Carbon is indeed very strong, but only in the way for which the frame was designed...it is not strong in all direction and certainly not hard. You'll have a relatively small choice of bike if you go for tit though...and carbon is far more forgiving and I love my carbon bike more than any of my others. My advice...test ride a few and see what you like.
Oh, and get a bike fit, whatever you decide you buy! Worth every penny. You may even be able to get one thrown in if you spend an appropriate amount at a decent LBS :) Hope that helps!

Although carbon is very stiff, when they design the frames, some of the tubes are designed to give a little, for example the seat stays and the forks. This means that they absorb some of the shock from bumps in the road, but at the same time the carbon in the bottom bracket and chain stays is extreamly stiff to transfer as much energy from your legs to the wheels. Titanium is the same all over. It certainly makes for a more comfortable ride, especially when you hid 3-4+ hours in the saddle. If you do decide with tit, you could improve the comfort of the ride with a carbon seatpost, and maybe 25c tyres anyway...lots of options!

WRITING.TEXT: I currently live with the union president and she got a lot of stick for this. People, really need to chill out, this is just a light hearted poster...is not like the union is celebrating fascism. I also don't understand who these sad people are that have enough time to complain and worry about such insignificant things.
MK 'Always' (Route 94 Remix) http://youtu.be/JhIxLJM2T5U

The point is it's just a poster. It's not recruiting, it's not creating and sense of offence, it's just a picture. It would be exactly the same if it were hitler. Nobody should care. It may offend some people...most definitely. Does that matter really? Not at all. To quote Stephen Fry "It's now very common to hear people say, 'I'm rather offended by that.' As if that gives them certain rights. It's actually nothing more... than a whine. 'I find that offensive.' It has no meaning; it has no purpose; it has no reason to be respected as a phrase. 'I am offended by that.' Well, so fucking what." If people are gunna moan about something, moan about something which matters or is really affecting people.

No the point is, is anybody being hurt by the poster...nope. It doesn't matter. It's just a waste of everybody's time. There are a near infinite list of things which are several orders of magnitude more important than this. Why not whine about something which would actually benefit from change.

WRITING.TITLE: What would be the consequence of wrongful prosecution by a company, when the problem turned out to be a software bug in the prosecuting company's software? (UK)
WRITING.TEXT: I am doing a small university project, where we are discussing the Post Office accounting system bug. Here's detailed summary: http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240089230/Bankruptcy-prosecution-and-disrupted-livelihoods-Postmasters-tell-their-story Essentially many post office masters have been prosecuted, due to supposed shortfalls in their takings. This has later been discovered to be due to a software bug in the post office accounting system. People have lost their houses, gone bankrupt and even a few have gone to prison. In the cases where people have gone to prison this is due to false accounting, because they were signing off accounts which were incorrect. In many cases this was because they feared that they would not be able to open the office the next day, and that they would lose more money. If this was the case, would there be any compensation for the post masters that went to prison? Although they did sign off the accounts, the only reason the accounts were wrong was because of the software bug. What rights would the post masters have? And for those who were forced to pay back money which was wrongly accounted for by the system, what rights do they have? Cheers guys!

One of the most important things is that the bike fits! Get the right frame size. In the UK a bike fit can cost between #163;40- #163;140, but it is really worth the money. Make sure you mark all the distances with tip ex though! If it fits right, you'll be more comfortable and be able to transfer power much more efficiently. A helmet. Hydration is also extremely important, so two bottles and bottle cages. A helmet. I would recommend getting a saddle bag, multi tool, tyre levers and a mini pump to take out on rides. As nice extras if you have the cash, some bib shorts (they go over your shoulders) will make riding more comfy. And clip less pedals and shoes. If it's your first clip less shoes, maybe go with SDP cleats and then you can use some double sided pedals so you don't have to worry about clipping in if you feel like it. A helmet. Also, download Strava, it's an app for recording routes and I personally find it fantastic motivation to push yourself and to beat your previous times! Free too! A bike computer might be nice to go with this too. Happy cycling!!!!

Road cyclist here. What ever you make sure you workout your whole body, not just legs. I tend to group: back and bis, chest and tris, legs and core, shoulders. On leg day, I do a variety of exercises but tend to have a higher number of reps per set for squats. 15-20. This will help build endurance, as well as muscle mass. Same when I do deadlifts on back day. If you're a keen cyclist you'll probably find that you'll be quite good at both deadlifts and squats from the off. I'm a more muscular rider, a sprinter, certainly not a climber. If you're a climber, this added muscle mass is almost certainly going to have a negative effect. I don't compete I might add, but do cycle around 4000km a year. I see this as a workout to make me fitter all round, in strength, and not just make me a bit better on the bike. That is just a bonus. I hope this helps.

Water. Food. Drink before you're thirsty. Eat before you hungry. Sip water as you ride. The more you eat on the bike (or during the ride at least), means you'll eat less afterwards and you'll have the calories when you need them. Oh and have a big breakfast.

A good mix of complex and simple carbs. I believe the idea ratio is 2:1 complex:simple. But unless you're a professional, just eat some fruit and something like a cereal bar. Maybe a jam sandwich. Nothing fancy, it's all the same, getting the ratio right is just marginal gains. Carb drinks and energy gels are fantastically convenient, however a little more expensive.

WRITING.TITLE: Good deed of the day. People cycling without lights at night. Help them out, give them some lights?
WRITING.TEXT: Today I was driving home from work (didn't cycle today I'm afraid) at night along an urban road without street lighting and almost hit a young LAD on a his bike as he had no lights. To be honest I was angry. I see somebody on their bike every week without lights without fail. I passed him safely and a little further down the road I remembered that I had some cheap LED lights (the ones which have the little loop of elastic to attach them) in the boot which I purchased before Christmas at Tesco as they were super cheap. I pulled over further down the road and flagged him down when he got to me. And I gave him a bit of a lecture (he was only 16/17) and gave him the lights and told him to put them on. After we managed to get the packet open, we put them on and he thanked me and then I drove off. Anyway this got me thinking, maybe I could always do this. So I've just purchased 2 more sets of front and back lights on eBay. Slightly better ones, with batteries and they were only #163;4. I intend to hand these out to people when I see them riding with no lights. Its a little thing but it could really save somebody's life. Maybe as a cycling community we could all do the same and help people out if you can? If you have an old set of lights, maybe you can just keep them in the car? Or just buy a cheap set next time your at the supermarket and hand them out when you see somebody riding dangerously?
"Ninja" I love it haha. Yes, these were #163;0.99 in the UK. Bargain!
TBH we could have done with a shop-mechanic just to get them out the packet! Damn packets are too strong!

WRITING.TITLE: How to compliment my savings. Nutmeg.com?
WRITING.TEXT: Hi guys I'm after a little advice! I #8217;m 23, recently graduated, have a well-paying job ( #163;39500) and my outgoings are pretty low. Monthly savings: - My work contribute 10% of my salary to my pension and to that I add another 7.5% to this I also get their national insurance saving. This comes to about #163;555 going in my pension pot each month which I can obviously not touch. - I put #163;300 into a savings account (currently paying 6% but capped @ #163;300/month) each month. - I have just opened a cash ISA which I will also put #163;300 in each month. Currently have. - #163;4k in pension pot. - #163;3000 in savings (total). - #163;1200 of shares in the place I work, which they have matched with a further #163;1200. The matched shares are locked in for 3 years, but I could withdraw the others if I really needed them. And after 5 years they will be totally tax free (so I probably want to keep these for 5 years). In total, I can afford to be putting away ~ #163;800 (excluding pension) and was thinking of investing in some shares. My goal is to have #163;35k in total 3 years from now for a house. So assuming all things remain the same I would already have. - #163;23600 + interest in savings accounts. - #163;2400 in work shares. To make up the rest #8230;. I have seen the website nutmeg (http://www.nutmeg.com/) which you can open an account with only #163;1000, and a minimum of #163;50p/m. I am considering opening with #163;1000, and a month contribution of #163;200 in a fairly high risk portfolio (level 8). The nutmeg performance suggests that with #163;1000 down and #163;200p/m after 3 years I would have contributed #163;7210 and the median portfolio worth could be #163;8739 (based on previous performance) #8230;obviously this could be a lot less. Is this nutmeg portfolio a wise decision to compliment my other savings? Could I do something better with the money? Advice much appreciated guys. Thanks!

No worries. I studied computer science and managed to get on to a banking graduate scheme. I still can't believe how lucky I've been!

What are you studying? And where? A have a tips which are no brainers. 1. Get experience. If your course does a year in industry (or similar) then take it, if not, intern during the summers, if not freelance. If you can, do them all. For me, my year in industry was wayyy more valuable than my degree. I learnt more in the first 3-4 months working in industry that I did in 2 years at uni. 2. Do the extra stuff, volunteer, travel, coach football, lead scouts, be part of a team for something. If you get to the interview (or assessment days) everybody will be as good as you on paper, you need to be able to show what you did to go the extra mile and that you're a nice person. You need to come across as an interesting person. Every boy seems to list his hobby as football, if I heard that in a interview I would just discard it. It really builds character. 3. Have examples of times when you've taken ownership and accountability for things. The grad schemes are often a way to slingshot people in to management. If you have examples which support their requirements well, and they think you have longer term potential its puts you in a good place. I #8217;m glad you #8217;re making big steps to improve your options; great subject and at a very good uni. The whole process moved incredibly quickly for me, but I wouldn #8217;t say this was the norm. From me clicking submit on the online application to receiving a job offer was exactly 2 weeks. The process was pretty standard, see below, but usually this would take much longer. Maybe even 2 months+. Most applications open late summer, to start a year later. Application process 1. Online application a. CV b. Covering letter c. Application specific questions (in my case, a couple of small essays about the future of the industry) 2. Online test a. Numeric b. Reasoning c. Interpersonal 3. 1st phone interview #8211; Mainly just a chat to make sure you can hold a conversation. Some questions like #8220;Tell me about a time you #8217;ve worked in a team. #8221; #8220;How would you handle a situation where you knew you could not deliver on time. #8221; 4. 2nd phone interview #8211; Technical. For me this included things about programming, and various other computer science things. 5. Assessment centre #8211; Put me up in a hotel in London for the night and the centre started very early the next morning. a. Meet and great breakfast with other applicants and senior employees who would later conduct interviews #8211; an ice breaker really b. 1st interview #8211; quality based, testing your morals and such, finding out a bit more about you and your hobbies, personality etc. Talk over your CV. c. 2nd interview #8211; technical, more course and role related questions #8211; in my case incredibly hard, but they don #8217;t expect you know the full answer, its often about approach d. Team task #8211; a problem solving task with 5 other applicants. Can be quite difficult, but you just need to show problem solving skills. e. Online tests retake #8211; this is just to make sure that you didn #8217;t cheat on the online exams. 6. Wait and see if you get an offer As I said for me all this only took 2 weeks. They were super organised. But for some of my friends it took months. As you said you #8217;re a mature student (I don #8217;t know how mature) but one of my colleagues who started at the same time as me was 33 and got on to same grad scheme I did. So you #8217;re still in the running for grad schemes all the same you would be for another job, and they #8217;re a brilliant way to go (certainly in finance industry, and chemistry as weird as it sounds is perfect to do so). You get a great wage, a decent golden handshake, the benefits are great (pension, share options, private healthcare), continued learning and genuine career progression opportunities. I am doing a couple of rotations in different roles to see what I like and where I want to build my career.

1. I boil the rice so its nearly done. 2. Fry the chopped thighs in a skillet (or wok). I use the 1 cal spray oil as you really don't need much as there is enough fat in the chicken itself, especially if you use a non stick pan. 3. Throw in a Knorr stock pot. It'll melt. 4. Pour the nearly cooked rice in to skillet with the chicken, and add a little hot water if there isn't much in with the rice. The water will absorb the stock. 5. Throw in the veg. 6. Simmer the whole lot on a low heat until its reduced and the liquid has been absorbed by the rice. Usually around 10 minutes. The end result is lovely tender chicken, and rice with flavour as well!

My brother and his girlfriend are also looking to buy in the near future, however he lives in a much more expensive part of the country and would need to spend more. And with the deposit they have, the LTV remaining would be more than 4x their combined salaries. Over drinks I suggested that maybe I could help them out, and buy the house with them, something like 80/20. It would help them out, and a bit of an investment for me. But what I don't understand is: * As I've only "used" 3x my salary for my mortgage, does this mean that effectively I could potentially get another mortgage for about #163;40k? (working on the premise that lenders typically would give a max of 4x salary) Does it work like that? Anything to consider as it would be [part of] a second property? * What are the other implications of getting a joint mortgage? We'd be paying for everything 80/20 split (deposit, fees, mortgage). Presumably legal fees would be more to set it up. Would interest rates be different? Anything else differ? * There would be effectively 3 people on the mortgage. My brother his girlfriend and me. They're not married but would split everything. So 40/40/20. Anything to consider here? Obviously there are lots of assumptions here, and I'm fully aware it would be down to finding a lender. I was just wondering if you could help point me in the right direction, or flag up any immediate blockers. Thanks!

WRITING.TITLE: How does the awesome 3D tilted view work on Google maps?
WRITING.TEXT: How have google have programmed [this](https://www.google.co.uk/maps/place/Verona+VR,+Italy/@45.4630717,9.1769767,186a,20y,90h,41.69t/data=!3m1!1e3!4m19!1m16!4m15!1m6!1m2!1s0x477f5f68699be0e3:0x53f85a636882595b!2sVerona+VR,+Italy!2m2!1d10.9916215!2d45.4383842!1m6!1m2!1s0x477eb1daf1d63d89:0x7ba3c6f0bd92102f!2sVenice,+Italy!2m2!1d12.3155151!2d45.4408474!3e0!3m1!1s0x477f5f68699be0e3:0x53f85a636882595b!6m1!1e1) view? I know there used to be wire models of building in all the big cities, but this now seems to work everywhere and with a satellite image overlay on it. My initial thoughts were that it was a combination of: - Some clever edge detection - Using the difference in perspective from multiple satellite images - LiDAR data from satellites - Possibly some data from the street view cars ...all fed in to an algorithm. It seems to work better in some places than others. The link above is a good example as you get see it working on the courtyards, balconies and trees.

For my final year project, we made an app that measured driving for fuel efficiency. Android app, that connected to cars via a Bluetooth OBDC chip, and measured, speed, revs, what gear you were in, etc from the car, and also how harshly you accelerated and braked using the phone accelerometer. It then allowed you to upload your drives and scores to a website. We got the prize for best project, mainly because the scope was really wide. Plenty of research on how the Bluetooth chip works, the algorithm for calculating an "ecoScore", field testing with different cars and OBDC chips, android app architecture, database architecture, quite a few different technologies, Java, JSON, HTML, and of course ending up with a real world product. My point here really is that usually the project doesn't really matter too much, but it should be something which allows you get as many marks as possible, and the best way to do that is by following a real world process of the SDLC.

Budgeting seems to be your problem I think. Download all your transactions in the past year and go through to classify them in to what was essential spending and what wasn't. Then work out your outgoings each month. You should have some idea on how much disposable income you've got, and how much you could save each month. Obviously give yourself some money to spend as you please. Each month, I would set aside the money for bills, food and other essentials, set aside what you're going to save (giving it to your mum isn't a bad idea) and then you'll know what you have left for the rest of the month.

It's very easy to get a job. However, experience gained during your studies; internships, sandwich year, etc go a very long way to making it even easier. It'll also drastically improve your skills. A year of real world commercial experience is worth 2 years at university in my opinion. It also sets you up for jobs in other fields too. Personally, a bachelors degree with experience is more than enough to get a decent job. Of course a masters could be beneficial, but would depend on experience and area of specialism. I would definitely take up computer science again; it's served me very well. I no longer work in a computer science related role, however it opened many doors and I do use more general skills developed during my studies and time as a coder daily. I would think about where things are heading and try to specialise in an emerging field if possible. Whatever you do, try to back it up with strong business and project management experience. It's ok being a good coder, but you'll go a lot further if you're the full package. Hope this helps!

If you're talking about KT tape here, there is absolutely no scientific evidence that it does anything beneficial at all. Pseudo science like this, which on the surface appears to do no harm, often does. It's not just through smaller things (like peeling off your skin like this); it can result in people not seeking proper medical advice and potentially failing to be treated properly. The level of harm caused can been significantly worse than what first appears to be the case.

WRITING.TEXT: It #8217;s a good thing that these are non-organic. #8220;Organic #8221; is in no way sustainable for anything. It also doesn #8217;t mean anything. It #8217;s completely unscientific, and is in no way better in terms of nutritional value, taste or cost. It #8217;s pure marketing. As for the other stuff...fair. What a waste.

I #8217;m not overly familiar with the specific regulations in the US (I #8217;m in the UK) but there is a similar framework in the EU. There are similar controls and hoops to jump through to get the EU organic certification, and the logo on foodstuffs, but it #8217;s equally useless. There are criteria that need to be met, but unfortunately the criteria don #8217;t improve the end product or safety (not that there is any truth in non-organic food stuffs being unsafe.) It only improves the perception of a better product. To take an example; you can #8217;t use glyphosate on a crop and call it organic. Which sounds sensible on the surface. Why would you put something with a chemically sounding name on food!? But in reality, glyphosate is not only one of the best herbicides that we have, it #8217;s been around for decades and has been proven repeatedly and scientifically to be safe. By being organic, what happens is farmers use other, new alternative herbicides and pesticides which are still #8220;chemicals #8221;, are still sprayed over the food...BUT for which we have no evidence of their long term effects. In addition to that you still have the same issues with yields being poorer, and no scientific evidence to show that the organic product is better.

My mum #8217;s neighbor is a massively depressed alcoholic. My mum has always got on well with her and she has lived there for 25 years. She has always had a bit of a problem, but her partner passed away a couple of years ago and she #8217;s been much worse since. She #8217;s up shouting and screaming most nights, pining for her partner. She bangs about, has a fallen down the stairs a number of times. It #8217;s a terrace and there are kids on the other side and they are woken weekly by it. And then a couple of months ago I was visiting and let myself in to mums and there was a slight burning smell. I was looking around and trying to find where is was coming from. Wasn #8217;t sure if Mum had burnt toast before going out, or it was a pump on the fish tank or something. But I go out side and can see smoke coming out of the air brick next door. I looked through the letter box and the smell hit me, and could see the hallway filled with smoke. I called the fire brigade and shouted through repeatedly to get her attention. Nothing. I then jumped over the back fence and could see her unconscious on the sofa through the patio doors. I battered the door but she was completely out of it. The fire brigade climbed through the window and threw her burnt dinner out. She nearly burnt down a terrace of house by passing out after cooking. It doesn #8217;t get much worse than that for neighbours. This makes my mum more anxious than ever.

Agree with this 100%. I did comp sci with business, and took the non- #8220;fluffy #8221; modules for both the tech and business side. Taking those related to algorithms, data, architecture, maths, accounting and law. All the other stuff like project management, industry, strategy etc can be learnt on the job. I now work as a business analyst/architect and sit much nearer the #8220;fluffy #8221; end of the spectrum in my day to day job, but there is absolutely no substitute for learning the key, more complex concepts. Either you #8217;ll take the real techy path and need the knowledge, or take the softer tech path and be drastically better at your job due to that background understanding.
Do a year in industry in the middle of your course. It #8217;s invaluable. You #8217;ll end up graduating with a decent degree and a great CV for somebody at that stage in their life.

I used to work at staples and the extra stock was stored in the #8220;windows #8221; above the shelves so there are big ladders on wheels in the aisles to put stuff up and take it down. He then let out an enormous fart. It was only then, standing directly behind him at the foot of the ladder, a woman piped up #8220;could you tell me where I can find elastic bands? #8221;. He nearly died of embarrassment, but has gone down in history.

This is largely because people do degrees with no career prospects. Practically everybody I know who did a #8220;proper #8221; degree (STEM or similar), either got a well paying job in their field, or a well paying job in an unrelated field because their degree demonstrated that they were intelligent and had real world skills. Unfortunately as interesting as history, drama, English, etc are, there are fuck all jobs specific to them with half decent salaries, that couldn #8217;t be completed by somebody else with a better degree to a higher standard.

Biology is probably the weakest of them, but the skills are highly transferable, and should be able to find work in unrelated fields very easily. The statistics, critical thinking, scientific process, scientific writing, attention to detail, proof you #8217;re not an idiot etc. are exactly what most companies (we certainly are at a bank) are looking for and would prioritise over a classics, or archeology student for example!

There is absolutely no link between Glyphosate and cancer. It has been proven repeatedly and scientifically that a link does not exist. Unfortunately, people don #8217;t like science and hate facts. Monsanto (or what used to be called Monsanto) are currently being sued by a number of people claiming that their cancer was caused by Round Up (brand name for Glyphosate) and in one case Monsanto may have to pay out a shit load of money because the courts have not listened to the experts who actually have the knowledge and have done the research, and instead ignored the facts. What actually makes this worse, is that we have a huge amount of evidence and long term studies to back up that Glyphosate is safe; more than any other pesticide. But much less about the alternatives. So by replacing Glyphosate with something else, the risk of adverse effects actually increases!
